feed.title: SAP Community - SAP AI Launchpad
feed.subtitle: SAP AI Launchpad Q&A in SAP Community

entry.title: Error: AI API call failed on the tutorial
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I'm currently following the tutorial Quick Start for Your First AI Project Using SAP AI Core and encountered an issue in Step 7: Check your scenario.

The error I'm seeing is:

AI API call failed. Check the error log for details. 
Error code: ERR_BAD_REQUEST 
Message: Request failed with status code 403

I followed the exact steps from the tutorial, including setting up a new repository and copying the provided YAML configuration:

apiVersion: argoproj.io/v1alpha1
kind: WorkflowTemplate
metadata:
name: first-pipeline # Executable ID (max length 64 lowercase-hyphen-separated), please modify this to any value if you are not the only user of your SAP AI Core instance. Example: `first-pipeline-1234`
annotations:
scenarios.ai.sap.com/description: "Introduction to SAP AI Core"
scenarios.ai.sap.com/name: "Tutorial"
executables.ai.sap.com/description: "Greets the user"
executables.ai.sap.com/name: "Hello Pipeline"
labels:
scenarios.ai.sap.com/id: "learning"
ai.sap.com/version: "1.0"
spec:
entrypoint: mypipeline
templates:
- name: mypipeline
steps:
- - name: greet
template: greeter

- name: greeter
container:
image: docker.io/python:latest
command:
- python3
- '-c'
args:
- |
print("Hello from SAP AI Core")

Are there any roles or permissions I might have missed on my SAP BTP subaccount? Or could the API endpoint be outdated or deprecated?

Here’s what I’ve tried so far:

  • Verified the YAML syntax and applied it without errors.
  • Checked my subaccount roles and added the recommended roles from the tutorial.

I'm pretty new to SAP and trying different tutorials to learn. I’d appreciate any pointers or advice. Let me know if I should provide more details!

Thanks in advance for your help!

SAP AI Core

entry.title: AI Launchpad: Grounding is not enabled
entry.content:
Hi Community,

In SAP AI Launchpad (standard plan), the "Grounding Management" menu is not visible. Additionally, when creating a new workflow, "Grounding" is disabled.

I have assigned the "grounding_manager" role to my user, along with all other roles listed in the document. Are any other setting required for using grounding?

entry.title: Replica Limit Exceeded During Deployment in AI Launchpad (Step 4 of Tutorial)
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I’m following the SAP AI Core tutorial "Deploy Your First Machine Learning Model", and I’ve run into an issue during Step 4: Start Deployment in the AI Launchpad.

Here’s the problem:

  1. When I start the deployment for the "House Price (Jan) metrics" configuration, I get the following status:

{
 "aiApiDetails": {
  "reconciler": {
   "message": [
    {
     "message": "Total number of Replicas (maxReplicas) 5 exceeded the maximum limit of 3 for the tenant 24006af3-fc34-4af2-b695-1d7fd76f1da7. Please modify the Replicas (maxReplicas) value less than or equal to the maximum limit of 3"
    }
   ]
  }
 }
}

  1. I’ve checked my current setup in AI Launchpad:

    • I have several scenarios, configurations, and executions, but I can’t figure out where these 5 replicas are coming from.

    • The Stop button is greyed out for some active deployments, so I can’t terminate them through the UI.

  2. Using the CLI, I attempted to list and manage deployments, but it’s unclear how to clean up or reduce the number of active replicas to stay within the limit.

Questions:

  • What exactly is a "replica" in this context? Is it tied to active deployments, configurations, or executions?

  • What causes the replica count to exceed the limit?

  • Is there a way to identify and terminate "stuck" replicas or unused deployments from previous steps?

  • How can I reset my environment or remove old configurations/deployments to resolve this issue?

I’m eager to complete the tutorial but am stuck at this point. Any guidance or suggestions would be greatly appreciated!

Thanks in advance for your help!

entry.title: SAP AI Launchpad Generic Secret Creation
entry.content:
Hi, 

I'm exploring SAP AI Launchpad Standard and I have issue while creating Generic Secret.

I'm using SAP BTP Object Store to store my data. During creation of Generic Secret I've received following error: 

{
    "error": {
        "code": "400",
        "message": "'authentication' is missing in data."
    }
}
I added two labels: 
document-grounding : true
documentRepositoryType : S3

With those labels (document-grounding to be specific) i got an error 

, my secret structure looks as follows: 

{"access_key_id": "base64encoded",
"bucket": "base64encoded",
"host": "base64encoded", 
"region": "base64encoded", 
"secret_access_key": "base64encoded", 
"uri":"base64encoded",
"username":"base64encoded"}

so indeed there is no authentication field but what should passed there in S3 scenario?
Additionaly, if I try to create generic secret without label document-grounding:true it is possible but if I then go to Grounding Management and try to create Data Repository following error appears

Error Code: 404
Message: Received not found from document grounding api = {'requestId': '1394b8d8-88a1-46ee-b840-3b6408aef4dd', 'code': 404, 'message': 'Destination in Configuration not found'}

BTW. I did try to create Generic Secret via Postman as well and the same error appears.
Any ideas? 
Kind regards

entry.title: Why Is My SAP AI Core Training Job Taking Much Longer Than Reported Duration?
entry.content:
Hi Community,

I'm currently working on a machine learning pipeline using SAP AI Core, where I trigger a training job via a workflow (training.yml) that pulls a training script and executes it.

However, I've noticed that there is significant configuration time before and after the actual training begins. The model training itself takes the same amount of time as before, but there are additional waiting periods both before the training starts and after it completes. For example, in the image below, although the duration is shown as 1 minute 22 seconds, the entire execution took around 10 minutes to complete.


Is there a recommended way to optimize or reduce this setup/configuration time?

here is my training.yml code:

 

apiVersion: argoproj.io/v1alpha1
kind: WorkflowTemplate
metadata:
  name: aicore-anomaly-training
  annotations:
    scenarios.ai.sap.com/name: "Aicore Anomaly Detection Scenario"
    scenarios.ai.sap.com/description: "Pipeline for anomaly detection"
    executables.ai.sap.com/name: "Anomaly AI Core Model"
    executables.ai.sap.com/description: "Trains anomaly detection models"
    artifacts.ai.sap.com/anomalymodel.kind: "model"
  labels:
    scenarios.ai.sap.com/id: "aicore-anomaly"
    ai.sap.com/version: "1.0"
spec:
  imagePullSecrets:
    - name: tanmay-credentials
  entrypoint: anomaly-pipeline

  arguments:
    parameters:
      - name: GUID
      - name: PLANT
      - name: NODE_PARAMETERS
      - name: NODE_ID
      - name: ALGORITHMS

  templates:
    - name: anomaly-pipeline
      outputs:
        artifacts:
          - name: anomaly-aicore
            globalName: anomalymodel
            path: /app/model
            archive:
              none: {}
      container:
        image: docker.io/tanmay471/anamoly_train_optimised:01
        command: ["/bin/sh", "-c"]
        env:
          - name: GUID
            value: "{{workflow.parameters.GUID}}"
          - name: PLANT
            value: "{{workflow.parameters.PLANT}}"
          - name: NODE_PARAMETERS
            value: "{{workflow.parameters.NODE_PARAMETERS}}"
          - name: NODE_ID
            value: "{{workflow.parameters.NODE_ID}}"
          - name: ALGORITHMS
            value: "{{workflow.parameters.ALGORITHMS}}"
        args:
          - "python /app/src/main.py"

entry.title: Oppt Prioritization score custom Agent in SAP CX AI Toolkit
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I am trying to create a custom AI agent for opportunities called Oppt Prioritization score agent. For this i created an AI Tool by giving the following prompt:

You are an opportunity prioritization agent in the SAP CX AI Toolkit for SAP Sales Cloud V2. Analyze all opportunities with Opprtunity.Status with Open status.

Calculate the prioritization score based on the following weighted criteria:
1. Opportunity.Expected_Value (50% weight)
2. Opportunity.Probability (30% weight)
3. Opportunity.Close_Date within 30 days from the Opportunity.Current_Date (20% weight)
Assumptions
4.Opportunity.Probability is assumed to be a percentage (0-100).
5.The Opportunity.Close_Date condition is binary, based on whether it falls within 30 days from the Opportunity.Current_Date, interpreted as future dates for prioritization.

Priotitization Score = 0.5*{Opportunity.Expected_Value} + 0.3*{Opportunity.Probability} + 0.2*{cases}
1 {ifOpportunity.Close_Date is within 30 days from the Opportunity.Current_Date} else
0
end{cases}

Provide a one-sentence explanation per opportunity justifying its ranking and, sorted by Amount (descending). Use a professional tone and avoid technical jargon.
For each opportunity, provide a brief, actionable follow-up recommendation (e.g., “Schedule a discovery call to discuss budget constraints”). Use a concise, professional tone and leverage intelligent Q&A to ensure recommendations are contextually relevant.
Include a summary of recent interactions for each opportunity, generated using the toolkit’s AI summary capabilities. Use a professional tone and ensure recommendations support team collaboration.
Ensure Output Fits Within 5000 Chatacters
Compact Formatting--> Remove unnecessary spaces & line breaks.
Limit Answer Length--> Max 500 Characters per answer, truncate with "..."

I assigned this AI tool to the custom AI Agent.The details (PFA screenshot) which are used are

Expected value = 15000 USD

Probability = 80

Close Date = 25 Jul 2025

The calculation for close date is incorrect, it should be 1, but it is coming as 0. Any suggestions how can i achieve the condition for the close date?

entry.title: Gemini API Integration Attempts and Current 404 Issue
entry.content:
Hi Developers,

We are encountering the following issue while integrating the Gemini model with SAP AI Core:

  • 404 Not Found is returned when calling the Deployment ID at the root URL, even when using the correct orchestration payload.

  • The deployment URL has been verified to match exactly.

  • Gemini API is confirmed to be up and running, and tests using logs captured from network activity match the expected configuration.

  • Despite this, the API call consistently returns:

    "The requested URL was not found on the server. If you entered the URL manually please check your spelling and try again."

Could you please confirm the correct deployment details or orchestration URL for the Gemini deployment, or advise on a possible workaround so we can proceed?

Best regards,
Aditya Srivastav

entry.title: Gemini API Integration
entry.content:
Hi Developers,

We are encountering the following issue while integrating the Gemini model with SAP AI Core:

404 Not Found is returned when calling the Deployment ID at the root URL, even when using the correct orchestration payload.

The deployment URL has been verified to match exactly.

Gemini API is confirmed to be up and running, and tests using logs captured from network activity match the expected configuration.

Could you please confirm the correct deployment details or orchestration URL for the Gemini deployment, or advise on a possible workaround so we can proceed?

Best regards,
Aditya Srivastav

entry.title: AI launchpad, Error Code: 04000001
entry.content:
Hi community,

It seems a mistake when I try to open the SAP AI launchpad, https://sap-learning-dev-venusaur.ai-launchpad.prod.eu-central-1.aws.ai-prod.cloud.sap/aic/index.html#/workspaces&/a/detail/TwoColumnsMidExpanded/?workspace=aicore-dev&resourceGroup=default

 

When I click 'view detail', it shows: it looks like something went wrong. Please check your details and try again.

Error Code: 04000001
Message: An API error is preventing access to the AI Core Administration app. Contact technical support.
 
 
When I used Python code locally to connect to the AI core and call the previously deployed AI Launchpad model, it was still possible to run.：
deployment_url = "https://api.ai.prod.eu-central-1.aws.ml.hana.ondemand.com/v2/inference/deployments/df48994be265dea9"
 
 
When I choose another api connection in API connection, it works. That means if I choose another api connection, I can see workspaces. generative ai hub, sap ai core administration and ml operations on the left side. 
 
 
This seems to be a problem with the front end. Whenever I click on any resource group, a 500 error is reported. The backend of Launchpad failed to call AI Core. The error did not occur in the browser, but within SAP Launchpad itself.
 

 

 
What should I do?

Thanks in advance.

entry.title: Vibe Coding with MCP Servers & SAP AI Core: Toward "Coding by Conversation"
entry.content:
Over the past few months, I’ve explored vibe coding — a workflow where you prompt the AI, it generates code, and you iterate. Fast and interactive, yes — but in enterprise projects, context and governance are critical. Without them, hallucinations and mismatched code structures quickly emerge.

This is where MCP servers (Model Context Protocol) and SAP AI Core become essential. Tools like fiori server and cap server allow AI assistants to understand your CDS models, Fiori metadata, and application structure — enabling contextual, reliable code generation.

In this blog, we’ll explore the architecture, practical usage, and enterprise best practices that make AI-assisted coding robust and production-ready.

What is Vibe Coding?

Vibe coding is a transformative approach to software development — essentially, coding by conversation.

  • You describe requirements in natural language.
  • The AI assistant interprets your intent and proposes code patches, scaffolding, or tests.
  • You review, refine, and approve the generated output.

The power of vibe coding lies in freeing developers from repetitive boilerplate tasks, allowing them to focus on high-value work like architecture, user experience, and business logic.

SAP’s reference architecture for vibe coding with Cline + SAP AI Core demonstrates how AI-assisted development can be safe, repeatable, and fully aligned with enterprise standards — turning AI from a helper into a structured development partner.

Core Principles from the SAP Architecture

From the reference architecture, five principles stand out:

  1. Prompt-Driven Development – Express features in natural language, and let the system automatically generate the initial scaffolding.
  2. Context Engineering – Supply LLMs with only the necessary structural context, such as APIs, CDS models, or MCP metadata.
  3. AI-Assisted Test-First Approach – Begin by generating tests, then guide the AI to produce code that fulfills those requirements.
  4. Human-in-the-Loop Governance – Developers retain responsibility for ensuring compliance, performance, and security.

Introducing MCP Servers

MCP (Model Context Protocol) acts as the bridge between your project and the AI assistant.

MCP (Model Context Protocol) is designed to act as a powerful bridge between your project and the AI assistant, ensuring that development is not just driven by prompts but also grounded in real project context. Instead of leaving the AI to guess or hallucinate about how your application is structured, MCP Servers provide it with a deep, contextual understanding of your project.

They expose key elements such as metadata, annotations, models, services, entities, relationships, and queries. This allows the AI to reason intelligently about your project’s architecture, whether it’s related to the user interface, the underlying data definitions, or the service layer.

With MCP servers running, your AI assistant doesn’t hallucinate blindly — it knows your project structure.

Architecture in Action: Cline + SAP AI Core + MCP

Here’s how the pieces fit:

  1. Cline –Your coding agent inside the IDE, mediating prompts, code diffs, and project changes.
  2. SAP AI Core – Hosts the foundation models (Claude, OpenAI, Gemini) in a governed, enterprise-ready environment.
  3. MCP Servers – mcp server expose structured context:
    • UI annotations, metadata, and manifest structure
    • Style guides and constraints
    • CDS entities and services

Workflow:

  • You prompt: “Create a ListReport for SalesOrder with a status field.”
  • AI (via MCP) inspects CDS models and annotations.
  • AI generates the CDS extension, Fiori annotations, and manifest changes.
  • You review, test, and deploy.

This architecture transforms AI coding from a “toy experiment” into a repeatable, enterprise-grade engineering practice.

How to Get SAP AI Core Credentials

  1. Access SAP BTP Cockpit: Go to your SAP BTP subaccount
  2. Navigate to AI Core: Services → Instances and Subscriptions → AI Core
  3. Create Service Key:
    • Go to your AI Core service instance
    • Create a new service key
    • Copy the credentials (clientid, clientsecret, url, serviceurls)
  4. Configure Authentication URL: Usually follows pattern https://{subdomain}.authentication.{region}.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token
  5. Set Base URL: Typically https://api.ai.ml.hana.ondemand.com (check your service key for the exact URL)
SAP_AI_CORE_CLIENT_ID=your-client-id
SAP_AI_CORE_CLIENT_SECRET=your-client-secret
SAP_AI_CORE_AUTH_URL=https://your-subdomain.authentication.sap.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token
SAP_AI_CORE_BASE_URL=https://base-ai-core-url
SAP_AI_CORE_RESOURCE_GROUP=your-resource-group

Refer to the screenshot below, which shows how we subscribed to the SAP AI Launchpad application to deploy our model according to the use case. We also created an SAP AI Core instance to obtain the necessary key details required for configuration in the Cline client.

Cline Configuration

  1. Install the Cline extension in VS Code
  2. Open Cline settings
  3. Configure these fields:
    • API Provider: Select "SAP AI Core"
    • Client ID: .clientid
    • Client Secret: .clientsecret
    • Base URL: .serviceurls.AI_API_URL
    • Auth URL: .url
    • AI Core Resource Group: Extract UUID from .appname (first part before the !)

       4. Test with a simple query to make sure it works

Add Server Configurations

To enable AI-assisted coding with full context, add the following server configurations to your cline_mcp_settings.json file. This configuration allows Cline to connect to the MCP servers that expose structured information about your project, including CDS models, Fiori metadata, manifest files, and coding style constraints. By providing these settings, you ensure that the AI assistant can:

  • Understand project structure: MCP servers give the AI visibility into your CDS entities, services, and UI annotations, allowing it to generate code that aligns with your existing models.
  • Follow enterprise standards: Style guides, naming conventions, and other constraints are passed through MCP servers, ensuring that generated code adheres to your organization’s best practices.
  • Generate context-aware code: Instead of generic snippets, the AI can create extensions, annotations, or manifests that fit seamlessly into your project.
  • Improve efficiency and reduce errors: By providing a structured context, the AI minimizes mismatches and hallucinations, letting developers focus on architecture, business logic, and user experience rather than repetitive boilerplate.

With the server configurations in place, Cline can interact with MCP servers in real time, making AI-assisted coding a safe, reliable, and enterprise-ready process.

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "cds-mcp": {
      "command": "cds-mcp",
      "args": [],
      "env": {},
    }
  }
}

Set Guardrails with Cline Rules (How-To)

Purpose: Provide persistent, project-level guidance — covering scope, coding style, documentation standards, and more — that’s always active in your workspace.

Cline Rules act as a continuous, automated advisor for your development team. By defining guardrails, you ensure that AI-assisted coding adheres to enterprise standards and project-specific conventions. This prevents inconsistent implementations, reduces technical debt, and maintains code quality across the team.

  1. Create a Rule File
    1. In Cline’s Rules tab, click “+” or use the command: /newrule.
    2. Save as a single file: .clinerules at the repo root, or use a folder-based setup .clinerules/ for multiple rules.
  2. Recommended Folder Structure
your-project/
├── .clinerules/
│   ├── 01-project.md      
│   ├── 02-coding.md
│   └── 03-documentation.md  
├── docs/
  • Each file addresses a specific aspect of project guidance: project scope, coding standards, and documentation expectations.

Example Prompt Flow

You: "Initialise an empty SAP CAP application in this folder."
AI: The empty CAP application has been successfully initialised in the current folder

 

You: "Generate an entities sales and sales order items"
AI: The entities is successfully created.

Result: you stay focused on implementing business logic and refining the user experience, while the AI assistant handles all the scaffolding, boilerplate, and repetitive code generation.

Open the Cline application and start the conversation with the above commands — this is where vibe coding truly comes alive, as your AI assistant (powered by MCP servers and SAP AI Core) begins generating context-aware code that you review, refine, and evolve into enterprise-ready solutions.

Once you select the Plan and submit the prompt, Cline (with MCP servers in the loop) interprets your intent, fetches the right CAP/Fiori context, and proposes structured code changes that you can review and refine into a production-ready solution.

You will now see a fully scaffolded CAP (Cloud Application Programming) application generated — with entities, services, and annotations created automatically based on your prompt, thanks to the MCP servers providing structured context to the AI assistant.

Benefits & Caution

Benefits

  • Faster Prototyping and Scaffolding – Quickly generate CAP entities, Fiori views, and annotations without manual boilerplate work.
  • Reduced Hallucinations – Structured context from MCP servers ensures AI proposals are relevant and accurate.
  • Freed Mental Bandwidth – Focus on UX, domain logic, and performance optimization, while AI handles repetitive scaffolding.
  • Aligned with SAP Standards & Governance – Generated code respects enterprise best practices and architectural guidelines.

Caution

  • MCP Servers Are Evolving – Always review AI-generated code before deployment.
  • Complex Business Logic Needs Oversight – Human expertise is essential for transactional integrity, security, and edge-case handling.
  • Prompt Precision Matters – Well-crafted prompts yield better, more reliable results.
  • Governance Remains Your Responsibility – Testing, security, and compliance cannot be fully delegated to AI.

Conclusion

Vibe coding isn’t just about writing code faster — it’s about reimagining how we build enterprise software. By combining AI assistants, SAP AI Core, and MCP servers, we provide AI the context it needs to act as a true development partner.

This approach lets developers move beyond boilerplate work and focus on what matters most: architecture, business logic, user experience, and innovation

Human expertise remains essential. Governance, compliance, performance tuning, and creativity stay firmly in the developer’s hands. But with vibe coding, tedious and repetitive tasks are no longer blockers — they’re delegated.

As these patterns mature, this may be remembered as the moment enterprise development evolved from “writing code” to “designing conversations.” The future of coding in SAP isn’t just AI-assisted — it’s context-aware, collaborative, and human-centered.
